DOC.HEAD: In Tents and Shelters, Panamanian Refugees Celebrate Christmas
With PM-Panama, Bjt
LaserPhoto PAN1
DOC.TEXT: Facing an uncertain future, thousands of people left homeless by the firepower of the U.S. troops who ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega lined up at a refugee camp for a Christmas dinner of GI rations. President Guillermo Endara and his vice presidents, Ricardo Arias Calderon and Guillermo Ford, visited the camp Monday for a Mass celebrated by Archbishop Marcos McGrath five days after the U.S. invasion. Residents swarmed around them, shouting ``Viva Endara!'' and ``Long live the civilian government!'' Endara won May elections that Noriega annulled. Christmas dinners were served in makeshift plastic shelters and large U.S. Army tents. ``We served more than 8,000 meals last night,'' Army Col. William Connolly said Monday. ``The lines were longer than we or they would have liked.'' Many of the refugees, their arms and legs in casts or bandages, quietly wondered what would happen to them now. They lost their homes in fighting between Noriega supporters and U.S. forces that attacked Wednesday to oust the military ruler. ``Well, you know, it's a place to stay meanwhile,'' said Pilab Rios, 40, a store clerk. ``It is safe here and there is food. Of course I am sad to have my home gone at Christmas, but I have my life and they say we will leave here in a few weeks.'' The camp is at Balboa Stadium and High School, just south of Panama City in the former Canal Zone near the canal administration building. The U.S. Army has erected 14 large tents and hopes to put up 14 more. Many of the homeless have patched together shelter from what was available. ``There are between 9,000 and 10,000 people here but you don't see that many now,'' said Connolly, a Boston native. ``A lot of them leave during the day to where their homes were and search for any belongings they can bring back here,'' he said. ``They come back in the evenings. We can estimate the population by the number of meals we serve.'' For many, the clothes they have on are all they managed to save. The camp is clean and orderly, and Connolly said it has extensive medical facilities. Both the troops and the homeless consider it fortunate that now is the start of the dry season in Panama, with no torrential rains expected. Organization of the camp has been turned over to Sergio Galvez, mayor of the Chorrillo district that surrounded Noriega's Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters. The district was devastated in the U.S. attack, and most of the camp residents came from there. ``I have been talking with presidential advisers and they are very willing to help rebuild,'' Galvez said. ``We all want to go back to Chorrillo. We hope the government of President Endara will solve this problem very quickly.'' Army Col. Jack Pryor said officials of the U.S. Agency for International Development are looking into an urban reconstruction program for Chorrillo. Galvez divided the camp into six sectors, based on people's neighborhoods before their homes were destroyed in the fighting. The homeless form orderly lines for Army rations. A few cooked rice or other staples over small fires. One family opened a small store with a few cans of food.
